raw_text:
UK TV channel rapped for CSI ad
 
 TV channel Five has been criticised for sending "offensive" and "threatening" advertising material to viewers for a new show about murder scene scientists.
 
 Five mailed thousands of fake dossiers including photos of murder victims and an e-mail suggesting the recipient was being stalked by a serial killer. Following complaints, the Advertising Standards Authority contacted Five to cease promotion of crime show CSI:NY. Five admitted it had sent out 55,000 promotion packs but had now stopped. The promotion material was sent in brown envelope of the type used by investigators in the series, a spin-off from the highly successful CSI: Crime Scene Investigation series, which also runs on Five. The pack also features pictures of forensic evidence from a crime scene and a wanted poster, which did have a CSI:NY logo printed in large at the bottom.
 
 Five said it had received 100 complaints but that it had been surprised at the reaction because it was "obvious this material is promoting a drama". A Five spokesman said: "In light of the efforts we have made to make the nature of the contents so transparent we are surprised a very small minority of recipients have mistaken it as anything else. "Everyone who was sent this promotion has expressed an interest in receiving details about this particular genre of programming on various websites. "We have also received emails and calls from recipients praising the originality and imagination of the campaign."
llama3.2:1b: UK TV channel Five has been criticised for sending fake dossiers to viewers for a new show about murder scene scientists, despite being clearly labelled as promoting a crime drama.
The promotion packs included photos of murder victims, an email suggesting the recipient was being stalked by a serial killer, and a wanted poster with a CSI:NY logo.
llama3.2:3b: Five sent 55,000 CSI:NY promotional packs with fake dossiers featuring murder victims and forensic evidence to viewers, sparking 100 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority.
gemma2:2b: TV channel Five sent out fake dossiers to viewers promoting a new show "CSI:NY", featuring murder scene photos, threatening emails, and a CSI logo.
The channel admitted sending 55,000 packs but has ceased promotion after complaints were lodged.
The Advertising Standards Authority was notified and the promotion material was deemed offensive by many.
Five claims it had a "transparent" intention to promote the show and some viewers praised its originality.

They sent out 55,000 promotion packs but stopped once complaints were raised.
The ad used a similar format to the highly successful CSI: Crime Scene Investigation, which also ran on Five.

The promotional materials were sent in brown envelopes used by crime scene investigators, featuring a CS:NY logo.
Despite admitting to mailing 55,000 packages, Five has since stopped the promotion following complaints.
qwen2.5:3b: UK TV channel Five criticized for sending fake dossiers, including photos of murder victims and a threatening email to viewers promoting crime show CSI:NY.

Over 100 complaints led to its cessation of promotion after admitting sending out 55,000 packs in investigator-themed envelopes with forensic evidence pictures and wanted posters featuring the show's logo.
Five defended itself by claiming recipients saw it as promotional material for a drama series, though some received emails praising the originality of the campaign.
opencoder:1.5b: The UK TV channel rapped for CSI ad promoted a new murder investigation show that it posted fake dossiers with photographs of the murder victims and an email suggesting they were being stalked.
The Advertising Standards Authority contacted Five to cease promotion, which was later confirmed by Five stopping after a series of complaints.

Five, however, had received 100 complaints but also praised the originality and imagination of the promotion campaign.
smollm:1.7b: The UK TV channel Five has been criticized for sending "offensive" and "threatening" advertising material to viewers for a new show about murder scene scientists, which is based on the popular CSI:NY series.
The channel mailed thousands of fake dossiers including photos of murder victims and an e-mail suggesting that the recipient was being stalked by a serial killer.
Following complaints, the Advertising Standards Authority contacted Five to cease promotion of crime show CSI:NY.
Five admitted it had sent out 55,000 promotion packs but had now stopped.
The promotion material was sent in brown envelope of the type used by investigators in the series, a spin-off from the highly successful CSI:Crime Scene Investigation series, which also runs on Five.
The pack also features pictures of forensic evidence from a crime scene and a wanted poster, which did have a CSI:NY logo printed in large at the bottom.
The channel said it had received 100 complaints but that it was "surprised at the reaction" because it was "obvious this material is promoting a drama".
A Five spokesman said: "In light of the efforts we have made to make the nature of the contents so transparent we are surprised a very small minority of recipients have mistaken it as anything else."
Everyone who was sent this promotion has expressed an interest in receiving details about this particular genre of programming on various websites.
"We have also received emails and calls from recipients praising the originality and imagination of the campaign," said a spokesperson for Five.
The channel's apology came after complaints that its promotional material was misleading and potentially harmful to viewers, particularly those who are vulnerable or sensitive.
Five has since apologized for any harm caused by its promotion and promised to take steps to prevent similar incidents in the future.

granite3.1-dense:2b: UK's Five TV channel faced criticism for promoting its crime show CSI:NY through controversial, offensive marketing materials.
The station mailed 55,000 fake dossiers to viewers, featuring photos of murder victims and a false stalking claim from a serial killer.

Despite 100 complaints, Five defended the campaign as transparent and praised for its originality.
Recipients reported interest in similar programming on other websites, and many expressed admiration for the campaign's creativity.
